title: Appointment of Chair in Geographies of Urban Inequalities (0.8 - 1.0 FTE)
job_description:
The chairholder will be appointed for 0.8-1.0 full-time equivalent (FTE). The appointee will be expected to contribute to research, teaching and management. The exact percentages depend on specific responsibilities and management tasks.


The Chair in Geographies of Urban Inequalities will focus on how new forms of urban inequality arise, existing forms are exacerbated and how inequalities are shaped by socioeconomic, spatial, and institutional contexts. Inequalities will be studied in relation to major societal processes, ongoing digitalization, and associated changes in urban economies and the transition toward post-Covid cities. In addition, implications of climate change, the energy transition, and the greening of economies for urban inequality are highly relevant. Such processes will be studied in cities both in the Global North and South, and may focus on specific demographic groups, such as youth, older adults, immigrants, low-income groups, racial and sexual minorities, or other groups.

employer_description:
Employer

Utrecht University is pleased to invite applications for a Chair in Geographies of Urban Inequalities. The Chair will be appointed at the Faculty of Geosciences and its Department of Human Geography and Spatial Planning.Â 


The Faculty of Geosciences at Utrecht University is the largest in the Netherlands, offering a comprehensive range of geosciences courses in both the sciences and social sciences. The Department of Human Geography and Spatial Planning is one of four departments at the Faculty of Geosciences and has its focus on the enhancement of long-term economic developments of cities, inclusion, and social inequalities in relation to transnational mobilities, the use of public space and health outcomes of urban living and the governance of urban sustainability transformations. The Departmentâs interdisciplinary Urban Futures Research Programme carries out path-breaking scientific research into the processes and governance arrangements that foster resilience, economic development, health and inclusion and sustainability in cities and urban regions, both in the Global North and South.
